data.text: Muscle Cramps after Long Distance Cycling
After long rides I get (seldom-but it happens) muscle cramp in one leg or the other during my sleep. Q: Do you ever do stretches after a ride or take hot baths? If stretches, what kind do you do?
Hydrate and electrolytes
data.author: Karen Robyn

data.text: Foam roller is a great tool.
data.author: Mark Anderson

data.text: I’ve always stretched.Google some. Quads hamstrings, calves, back and arms breaks up the lactose apparently and keeps ypu supple. There is so science now suggesting that pre stretching is a waste of time or even harmful. Just keep yer knees warm. Set of leg warmers is good at the start or if things become inclement.
data.author: Alex Gee

data.text: Look at nutrition too. Once I identified my magnesium, calcium and potassium needs I stopped getting chronic cramps. I had disabling cramps for decades, on and off. Hydration but also nutrients, especially as we get older, are key to tackling cramping.
data.author: Michael Manning

data.text:
can't be wrong, or not? You should stretch all the muscles that had been involved before while cycling. Examples e.g. here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1VCM7xnL2QY And also a warmup before starting might be an idea. But in real world, if you are not a professional, who does (as long as there are no problems)? Happy cycling!

data.text: Yep already out-eat the biggest gorilla!

data.author: Doug Walker

data.text: After long rides, I sleep with Hydrate and electrolytes next to the bed. If I wake up with the charley horse, I quickly consume both and they go away real fast!
data.author: Sam Carleton

data.text: I have the following routine post-exercise: stretch extensively, then legs vertically up against the wall lying on uour back for 10-15 minutes, then shower, alterating warm and cold (the colder the better). Then massage muscles with an oil, I have one with Arnica which is good. If I have sweat a lot in hot weather I drink half a liter of orange juice with ice cubes, a dissolved magnesium tab and half a teaspoon of salt. Doesnt taste great but gives you sugar salt and minerals to recover
data.author: Hajo Reuter

data.text: Stretching is a good idea, but leg cramps at night are all about hydration and electrolytes.
data.author: Larry Sanders

data.text: do both el+hydrate.
data.author: Ólafur Þórðarson

data.text: Try my natural hydration drink: orange juice, honey & pink Himalayan salt, with water. I also drink a glass of water before any meal stops/coffee/tea stops.
data.author: Liz Barroeta

data.text: Hydration is the key... 2 sips of water every 1 kms... or you figure out what works for you best... during summers or winters, day or night.
data.author: Amrit Rajkhowa

data.text: Replenish your electrolytes before you go to bed.
data.author: Jean Phillips

data.text: Hot baths is only when You have been exposed to a lot of cold. To avoid cramps, normaly cold baths. And yes. A lot of stretching. It's normaly my half hour straight after riding. And water.
data.author: Dani Martinez Fernandez

data.text: Hydrate and replenish electrolytes... can be as simple as a glass of water and a banana.
data.author: Richard Roussy

data.text: It's a thing for sure, water and consistent stretching and, occasionally, it still happens. I think it's both strengthening and exhaustion..... I'm sure alcohol doesn't help.
data.author: Samuel Lea

data.text: magnesium tablets on a long tour worked fantastically for both cramps and general fatigue - none of the day-after stiffness and heaviness.
data.author: Jennifer Chan

data.text: interesting. I should try those for my 100+ milers coming up
data.author: Ólafur Þórðarson

data.text: I stand at a kerb with my toes on the kerb and my feet in the road to stretch my hamstrings. I also have a soak in a bath with Epsom salts in.
data.author: Liz Barroeta

data.text: Stretch a LOT! Before, after, during! Also drink good electrolytes (Skratch Labs is my choice!)
data.author: Chris Bussiere

data.text: I find I usually cramp when my fluid intake was not adequate but electrolytes are important too.
data.author: Barbara Hart

data.text: I make sure I get all of my main salts, and I no longer get cramps. I used to suffer terribly. I add salt and baking soda, and fruit juice (or concentrate) to my drink bottle on a ride. Acid to react with the soda so that it does not taste soapy. Bananas for potassium and magnesium, my on ride snack.. Plus leafy greens for magnesium with normal meals. Calcium tablets. One on a normal day, two on a ride day.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Get yourself some Theraworx for cramps. It's for external use and it works.
data.author: Carol Maher

data.text: I drink LOTS of water before, during,and after the ride, PLUS eat foods high in magnesium. No cramps!
data.author: Kibbe McClod

data.text: No solution, but I have a story. After a 137-mile day (fully loaded), I was sitting at a bar in a little Nebraska town where I had treated myself to a room. Suddenly I got a very severe muscle cramp in my left leg and had no choice but to fall to the floor, writhing in agony. And everyone moved to the other end of the bar. About 20 minutes later, the same thing happened with the other leg -- with the same result. This time they called the police.
data.author: Michael Hudson

data.text: oh my, did they get you some medical attention?
data.author: Rachel Katherine

data.text: No, it was just a muscle spasm. It was actually the sheriff that responded, and after convincing himself that I was neither deranged nor dangerous, he listened to my explanation and then recommended bananas and beer. The latter was already ongoing. The former had to wait until the town's only grocery opened in the AM.
data.author: Michael Hudson

data.text: Oh my, sorry, I know that was terribly painful but the bar scene reads like from a movie. Did anybody talk to you while you were cramping in pain??
